Detector.Details: This detector finds types that extend concrete (i.e. non-abstract) types.
This detector finds method signatures using types declared as final (which breaks Mockito).
This detector finds types declared as final (which risks breaking Mockito).

BugPattern.Details: Subclassing concrete types is fragile. Extract a common abstract superclass or interface, or use a proxy to implement the delegation pattern. See also Antipattern: Final classes

BugPattern.LongDescription: Parameter {0} of {2} is of final type {3}
BugPattern.Details: Using final types in method signatures breaks proxying utilities like Mockito. Extract an interface, or remove the final keyword and hide the constructor instead. See also Antipattern: Final classes
Using final types in method signatures breaks proxying utilities like Mockito. Extract an interface, or remove the final keyword and hide the constructor instead. See also Antipattern: Final classes

Marking types as final breaks proxying utilities like Mockito. Prefer hidden constructors and static factory methods—or just trust your users not to do anything stupid. See also Antipattern: Final classes
